Description: The SEC sanctioned 13 firms for violating a rule primarily designed to protect retail investors in the municipal securities market. In its surveillance of trading in the municipal bond market, the SEC Enforcement Division's Municipal Securities and Public Pensions Unit detected improper sales below a $100,000 minimum denomination set in a $3.5 billion offering of junk bonds by the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.
The SEC announced enforcement actions against 36 municipal underwriting firms for violations in municipal bond offerings.

The SEC, the North American Securities Administrators Association, NASD Inc., the New York Stock Exchange and state securities regulators announced that Thomas Weisel Partners LLC would pay $12.5 million to settle allegations that its investment banking interests had undue influence on its securities research.
Stifel, Nicolaus & Co., Inc. agreed to pay $2.7 million to settle allegations of providing incomplete and inaccurate securities trading information to the SEC.

Agency: Connecticut Securities and Business Investments Division

Description: Stifel, Nicolaus & Company agreed to pay $531,385 in restitution, $70,000 in costs and $500,000 to the Investor Education and Protection Fund in settlement of allegations it failed to reasonably supervise an agent who was convicted of fraudulent securities sales.

The Bureau of Securities signed a final Consent Order that required Stifel Nicolaus & Company, Inc., to repurchase auction-rate securities (ARS) from New Jersey clients to settle allegations that the firm's securities dealers sold ARS without disclosing known risks of the ARS market.
Info Source: Stifel Nicolaus to Repurchase $5.4 Million in Auction Rate Securities from N.J. Investors, Targeted News Service, November 9, 2010 (via Nexis).

Description: Stifel, Nicolaus agreed to pay $525,000 to a group of states to resolve litigation alleging it failed to properly train employees to inform investors about the risks of auction-rate securities.

Thomas Weisel Partners agreed to pay $5 million to a group of states to settle allegations that its investment banking interests had undue influence on its securities research. This was part of a larger $12.5 million settlement involving the SEC; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-thomas-weisel-partners-llc

FINRA ordered Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated to pay approximately $1.9 million in restitution, plus interest, to more than 1,700 customers in connection with early rollovers of Unit Investment Trusts (UITs). FINRA also fined the firm $1.75 million for providing inaccurate information to customers related to rollover costs incurred, and for related supervisory violations.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered five firms to pay restitution estimated at more than $18 million, including interest, to affected customers for failing to waive mutual fund sales charges for eligible charitable organizations and retirement accounts.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered two St. Louis-based broker-dealers - Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated and Century Securities Associates, Inc. - to pay combined fines of $550,000 and a total of nearly $475,000 in restitution to 65 customers in connection with sales of leveraged and inverse exchange-traded funds (ETFs). Stifel and Century are affiliates and are both owned by Stifel Financial Corporation.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined 19 broker-dealers a total of $2.8 million for substantially overstating their advertised trade volume to three private service providers.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD ordered Thomas Weisel Partners of San Francisco, CA to pay $1.75 million for engaging in improper initial public offering (IPO) allocation practices and for failing to retain e-mails. That total represented $1.3 million in ill-gotten profits and an additional $450,000 fine.
Info Source: Thomas Weisel Partners to Pay $1.75 Million to Settle NASD Charges of IPO, E-Mail Retention Violations, PR Newswire, March 30, 2005 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined five brokerage firms a total of $625,000 for failing to implement adequate supervisory systems and written procedures reasonably designed to detect and prevent late trading of mutual funds.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD Regulation, Inc. censured and fined Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Inc. of St. Louis, MO for violating NASD rules in connection with the sale of Class B mutual fund shares.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).
